newsitem.title: UK: Pakistani leaders pay tribute to dead singer.
newsitem.headline: Pakistani leaders pay tribute to dead singer.

text.p: Pakistan's top classical singer Nusrat Fateh Ali Khan, who mixed traditional mystic music with modern fast beats, died on Saturday in a London hospital, a close British friend said.
Iftikhar Quaisar said Nusrat, 49, died of cardiac arrest after being admitted to hospital a few days earlier suffering from hepatitis.

Pakistan's official APP news agency said the singer was taken to hospital after he suffered "complication of renal failure due to diabetes". He had left Pakistan for the United States last week for a kidney transplant but stopped over for a few days in London, where his condition deteriorated, APP reported.
Pakistan's President Farooq Leghari and Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif issued condolence statements, calling the singer's death a national loss, according to state television.
Nusrat's body is to be flown back to Pakistan on Sunday for burial, APP said.

The scion of a family known for its attachment to classical music, Nusrat popularised the region's traditional mystic "Qawali" form of music and semi-classical Pakistani music in the West by mixing it with popular modern fast beats.
He composed music for several foreign films, including Hollywood's "Last Temptation of Christ" and India's controversial Hindi film "Bandit Queen".
Nusrat received France's FNAC award for music, Japan's Fukuoka award and Pakistan's Prime of Performance.
His family had migrated to Pakistan from the town of Jullundur in India's Punjab state at Partition in 1947.
